facts.text: This is an appeal from an order of the Madras High Court dismissing the petition of the appellant praying for a writ of certiorari.

anchor.surface_text: Fazl Ali, J. This is an appeal from an order of the Madras High Court dismissing the petition of the appellant praying for a writ of certiorari.

facts.text: The appellant was one of the persons who had filed nomination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was one of the persons who had filed numberination papers for election to the Madras Legislative Assembly from the Namakkal Constituency in Salem district.

facts.text: On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that constituency took up for scrutiny the nomination papers filed by the various candidates.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th November, 1951, the Returning Officer for that companystituency took up for scrutiny the numberination papers filed by the various candidates

facts.text: On the same day he rejected the appellants nomination paper on certain grounds.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day he rejected the appellants numberination paper on certain grounds which need number be set out as they are number material

facts.text: The appellant thereupon moved the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his nomination paper.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon moved the High companynrt under article 226 of the Constitution praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his number

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: ination paper and to direct the Returning Officer to include his name in the list of valid numberinations to be published. The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The appellants contention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is not correct that the view expressed by the High Court is not affected by article 329(b) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is number companyrect that the view expressed by the High Court is number affected by article 329 b  of the Constitution and that he was entitled to a writ of certiorari in the circumstances of the case.

facts.text: The High Court dismissed the appellants application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had numberjurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution.

facts.text: The Returning Officer rejected the appellants nomination paper.

anchor.surface_text: and on the same day he rejected the appellants numberination paper on certain grounds which need number be set out as they are number material to the point raised in this appeal.

facts.text: The grounds for rejection are not material to the point raised in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: rejected the appellants numberination paper on certain grounds which need number be set out as they are number material to the point raised in this appeal.

facts.text: The appellant prayed for direction to the Returning Officer to include his name in the list of valid nominations to be published.

anchor.surface_text: praying for a writ of certiorari to quash the order of the Returning Officer rejecting his numberination paper and to direct the Returning Officer to include his name in the list of valid numberinations to be published.

facts.text: Seven other State High Courts have held that they have no jurisdiction under article 226 to entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: We are informed that besides the Madras High Court seven, other State High Courts have held that they have numberjurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution of the entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of numberination papers.

facts.text: The appeal is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be numberorder to companyts.

facts.text: The Representation of the People Act, 1951 was passed by Parliament under article 327 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The Representation of the People Act, 1951, which was passed by Parliament under article 327 of the Constitution, makes detailed provisions in regard to all matters and all stages companynected with elections

facts.text: In section 100 of Representation of the People Act, 1951, one of the grounds for declaring an election to be void is the improper rejection of a nomination paper.

issues.text: whether the view expressed by the High Court is not correct that it is not affected by article 329 b of the Constitution and that he was entitled to a writ of certiorari

issues.text: whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question

anchor.surface_text: Now, the main controversy in this appeal centers round the meaning of the words no election shall be called in question except by an election petition in article 329 b , and the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper can be said to be comprehended within the words, no election shall be called in question.

issues.text: the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b

anchor.surface_text: As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning.

issues.text: whether the law of elections in this country contemplates that there should be two attacks on matters connected with election proceedings, one while they are going on by invoking the extraordinary jurisdiction of the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution and another after they have been completed by means of an election petition

anchor.surface_text: The question now arises whether the law of elections in this country contemplates that there should be two attacks on matters connected with election proceedings, one while they are going on by invoking the extraordinary jurisdiction of the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution (the ordinary jurisdiction of the courts having been expressly excluded), and another after they have been completed by means of an election petition.

issues.text: whether section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 would be ultra vires inasmuch as it confers on the Returning Officer a jurisdiction which article 329 b confers on a Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: it was further argued that section 36 of Act XLIII of 1951 would be ultra vires inasmuch as it confers on the Returning Officer a jurisdiction which article 329 b confers on a Tribunal to be appointed in accordance with the article.

arguments.claim: Seven other State High Courts held no jurisdiction under Art 226 for improper rejection of nomination papers

arguments.claim: Scheme of Part XV and RoPA is complete code postponing all disputes to election petition after election

anchor.surface_text: Article 329 is the last article in Part XV of the Constitution, the heading of which is Elections [...] providing the entire ground work for enacting appropriate laws and setting up suitable machinery for the conduct of elections.

holdings.text: The High Court has no jurisdiction under article 226 of the Constitution to entertain petitions regarding improper rejection of nomination papers by reason of article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the appellants application on the ground that it had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the Returning Officer by reason of the provisions of article 329 of the Constitution. The appellants contention in this appeal is that the view expressed by the High Court is not correct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 329(b) provides that no election shall be called in question except by election petition; rejection of nomination is part of election process covered by it, ousting writ jurisdiction; affirmed by multiple High Courts.

holdings.text: Questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper is comprehended within the words 'no election shall be called in question' in article 329(b).

anchor.surface_text: Now, the main controversy in this appeal centers round the meaning of the words no election shall be called in question except by an election petition in article 329 b , and the point to be decided is whether questioning the action of the Returning Officer in rejecting a nomination paper

holdings.reasoning_summary: Improper rejection is a ground under s.100 RoPA to void election; must be raised via election petition post-election, not intermediately.

holdings.text: The word 'election' in article 329(b) and Part XV bears a wide meaning, connoting the entire process culminating in declaration of elected candidate, including nomination scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long usage, precedents (Srinivasalu, Sat Narain), consistent with 'conduct of elections' in Art 324; narrow sense limited to poll result insufficient.

holdings.text: The law of elections does not contemplate two attacks on election matters: one under article 226 during proceedings and another by election petition after completion.

anchor.surface_text: The question now arises whether the law of elections in this country contemplates that there should be two attacks on matters connected with election proceedings, one while they are going on by invoking the extraordinary jurisdiction of the High Court under article 226 of the Constitution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of Part XV and RoPA is complete code with exclusive post-election remedy via special tribunal; dual remedies lead to conflicts and delays.

holdings.text: Where a statute creates a right/liability and provides special remedy (election petition), that remedy alone must be followed; no jurisdiction under article 226.

anchor.surface_text: It is not well-recognized that where a right or liability is created by a statute which gives a special remedy for enforcing it, the remedy provided by that statute only must be availed of. This rule was stated with great clarity by Willes J. in Wolverhampton New Water Works Co. v. Hawkesford

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusive statutory remedy doctrine from Wolverhampton, approved in Neville, Privy Council cases; applies to RoPA rights enforced only by election petition.

holdings.text: Section 36 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 is not ultra vires article 329(b); Returning Officer's scrutiny is a stage in election process, not questioning the election.

anchor.surface_text: it was further argued that section 36 of Act XLIII of 1951 would be ultra vires inasmuch as it confers on the Returning Officer a jurisdiction which article 329 b confers on a Tribunal to be appointed in accordance with the article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: RO performs duty to ensure compliance before election; single step not equivalent to calling election in question; tribunal handles vitiating disputes post-election.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal must therefore fail and is dismissed. In view of the nature and importance of the points raised in this appeal, there should be no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; High Court view affirmed.

holdings.text: The powers of the High Court under articles 226 and 227 and of this Court under article 136 in election matters to be decided on a proper occasion.

anchor.surface_text: the question as to what the powers of the High Court under article 226 and 227 and of this Court under article 136 of the Constitution may be, is one that will have to be decided on a proper occasion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not necessary for this case; reserved.

As we have seen the most important question for determination is the meaning to be given to the word election in article 329 b . That word has by long usage in connection with the process of selection of proper representatives in democratic institution, acquired both a wide and a narrow meaning.
